questions.text: A 45 year old woman noticed mass in her left breast with bloody discharge. Histopathologic picture of the lesion is given below. The treatment is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - The picture shows dilated ducts with secretions and lipid laden histiocytes indicative of Duct ectasia - Hadfield’s operation (excision of all major ducts) is the treatment of choice - The disease is more common in smokers and cause slit like nipple retraction

choices.text: Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of breast
Cord like appearance of subcutaneous veins
NSAIDs and warm compresses can produce resolution

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the condition shown in the picture below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - The condition depicted is Mondor’s disease or ‘String phlebitis’ - Lateral thoracic, thoracoepigastric and superficial epigastric veins are commonly involved

choices.text: Mucocele of maxillary and ethmoid sinus

questions.text: A child presents with a swelling as shown in the picture below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Meningoencephalocele is the herniation of meninges and brain which presents as a cystic swelling which is expansile, translucent, compressible and brilliantly transilluminant

questions.text: The following appearance of esophagus in barium swallow is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - The normal sequential paralysis is replaced by uncoordinated simultaneous contractions the produce curling in the wall, pseudodiverticula and sacculations called the cork screw esophagus

choices.text: It is inherited in autosomal recessive fashion
It is a risk factor for Renal cell carcinoma
It is usually caused by a single gene mutation on chromosome 16

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding the condition in a 40 year old male shown in the picture below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Adult polycystic kidney disease is inherited in autosomal dominant fashion - It occurs due to mutations in Polycystin 1 and 2 genes in chromosomes 16 and 4 respecively - It is not a premalignant condition

questions.text: What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - The clinical signs shown are Cullen sign (periumbilical bluish hue) and Grey turner’s sign (discolouration of flanks), both of which signify an intraperitoneal bleed as in acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with left lower quadrant pain, tenderness, and rebound tenderness on examination. He was afebrile and the blood tests were normal. The abdominal CT is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - The abdominal CT showed a hypodense pericolonic oval mass of 2•5 cm with adjacent fat stranding: a classic picture of epiploic appendagitis - Epiploic appendages are roughly 50—100 pedunculated adipose structures protruding from the serosal surface of the colon from the caecum to the rectosigmoid junction. - Torsion of the pedicle or central venous thrombosis could cause epiploic appendagitis, which can simulate diverticulitis, appendicitis, and cholecystitis.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - The radiograph shows a haustral pattern of subdiaphragmatic lucency, overlapping the upper border of the liver shadow. - The visualisation of a gas filled transverse colon lumen interpositioned between the right hemidiaphragm and the liver on a chest film is called Chilaiditi's sign.

questions.text: The appearance shown in the radiograph is most probably due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - The radiograph shown a thin layer of air within the bladder wall - It is most probably due to emphysematous cystitis caused by gas producing organisms like Enterobacter cloacae - It usually presents with non specific symptoms like lower abdominal pain, hematuria, pyuria etc

questions.text: What is the name of the characteristic appearance marked by an arrow in the picture below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - The arrow points towards a ureterocele which is the cystic swelling of the terminal portion of ureter - produces the characteristic ‘cobra-head’ or ‘adder-head’ deformity

questions.text: The picture shown below depicts a renal anomaly. Which of the following is not true of this condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Heminephrectomy does not improve renal fuction

questions.text: The given radiograph in a neonate is diagnostic of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - The radiograph shown is a classical depiction of ‘Pneumatosis intestinalis’ (gas in the bowel wall) that occurs in necrotising enterocolitis - Modified Bell’s staging is used in grading the condition

questions.text: The characteristic endoscopic appearance of the stomach shown below is produced by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - The picture shows the characteristic ‘watermelon stomach’ seen in Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) - Argon laser coagulation is used as treatment

questions.text: The primary in which of the following sites most commonly accounts for the condition of the liver shown in the figure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Among the options, Gall bladder is the most common site of primary in multiple liver metastasis

questions.text: The most common cause for the appearance shown in the chest xray is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - The chest radiograph depicts multiple rounded metastatic lesions in lung described as ‘cannon ball lesions’ - Renal cell carcinoma is the most common source of cannon ball metastasis followed by testicular cancer

questions.text: The radiograph shown below is indicative of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - The radiograph shows the ‘Triple bubble sign’ seen in jejuna atresia - Double bubble sign is seen in duodenal atresia and annular pancreas while multiple bubbles appear in ileal atresia

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - The instrument shown is Morris retractor used for tissue retraction in appendectomy, thyroidectomy, mastectomy etc

questions.text: Identify the instrument
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Babcock’s tissue forceps

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used in which of the following surgeries?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Kocher’s thyroid dissector: used during thyroid surgeries to dissect superior thyroid pedicle

questions.text: The painless ulcers shown here developed in a 55-year-old man with diabetes who did not recall any antecedent trauma. What type of ulcer is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - The ulcer developed is probably a neurotrophic one since it is painless - Ulcers of vascular origin are generally painful in nature

questions.text: A 34-year-old male smoker reports having rest pain and lower extremity digital ulcers for 2 months. He also reports a 1-year history of claudication. Which one of the following is the best means of preventing amputation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - The history and physical examination is consistent with Buerger’s disease (TAO) - The cornerstone of TAO management is smoking cessation

questions.text: A 55-year-old man had the painless lesions shown here. Biopsy reveals carcinoma in situ. What is this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Lesions are slightly raised, velvety, shiny, erythematous to violaceous plaques that are dry, may be scaling, and are usually painless - Lesions occur on the glans penis, prepuce, or urethral meatus - Surgical removal of the involved areas with 5-mm margins virtually eliminates the risk of invasive squamous cell carcinoma. - Topical laser treatments and 5-fluorouracil have been used for extensive involvement

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presented with mild abdominal pain, mild constipation with a feeling of incomplete evacuation and mucus in stools for the past 4 years. On examination, tenderness present on left iliac fossa. Barium enema picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Diverticula is the most common cause of significant lower GI bleeding - Most common site: Colon (Sigmoid colon) - Investigation of choice for diverticulosis: Barium enema - Best method of diagnosis and treatment: Colonoscopy

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with fatigue, right flank pain, and ankle edema. Laboratory studies show increased liver enzyme values and microscopic hematuria. The picture CT scan abdomen is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - Triad of clinical features of RCC are hematuria, abdominal pain and palapable mass - Stauffer syndrome is abnormal LFT in the setting of RCC, which is not due to metastasis rather by cholestasis

questions.text: Identify the investigation used:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - HIDA (Hydroxy Imino DiAcetic acid) scan helps to track the production and flow of bile from the liver into small intestine

questions.text: A child had a history of stab injury on the anterior abdominal wall and the image is shown below. The child is hemodynamically stable. Which will be the next course of treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Emergency laparotomy The next course of treatment in the given scenario of a stab injury to the abdomen with the image showing evisceration of the omentum is emergency laparotomy. Emergency laparotomy is performed to explore and repair abdominal injuries in case of - Hemodynamic instability - Peritonitis - Evisceration - Diffuse abdominal pain

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below that is used to create a pneumoperitoneum ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Veress needle The given Image showing a long, slender laparoscopic instrument is Veress Needle. It is used in direct puncture laparoscopy to produce a pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing an open cholecystectomy and uses the following instrument to lift the liver up. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Deaver’s retractor The given image is of the Deaver’s Retractor. It is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

questions.text: A patient was received in the casualty following a road traffic accident. His BP was 90/60 mmHg and his pulse rate was 120/min. The emergency room physician asked you to replace the fluid loss in this patient. What is the maximum flow rate of fluid with the IV canula given in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 90 ml/min The green IV cannula used in this hemodynamically unstable patient is an 18G cannula, which has a maximum flow rate of 90 ml/min.

choices.text: To hold tough tissue like skin and fascia

questions.text: For what purpose would you use the instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) To carry out blunt dissection The above Image is of Lister’s sinus forceps which are used for blunt dissection. It is used during Hilton’s method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection The given condition is likely to be Fournier gangrene. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection. Fournier’s gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, and diabetes. The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa, and Colles fascia.

questions.text: A peripherally Inserted central catheter line(PICC) was placed in a patient to provide parenteral nutrition. Following the insertion, a chest X-ray was taken, which appeared as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the ideal position of the tip of this catheter?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superior vena cava The ideal position of the tip of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, is superior vena cava. Peripherally inserted central catheters are commonly used for providing parenteral nutrition therapy. They are inserted through veins in the upper arm, and guided into the central venous system, such that the tip of the catheter enters the superior vena cava. A chest X-ray is taken to confirm the position of the tip. PICC lines have the advantage of minimizing inconvenience to the patients and clinicians. However, if the patient develops thrombophlebitis, the PICC line may be destroyed.

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency department after RTA with complaints of chest pain and breathing difficulty. An X-ray was done and is given below. What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient? RTA-Road Traffic Accident
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Paradoxical The type of breathing pattern observed in this patient with the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggestive of a flail chest is paradoxical respiration. A flail chest usually results from blunt trauma associated with 3 or more rib fractures in 2 or more places. It arises when these injuries cause a part of the chest wall to move independently of the rest of the chest wall. It is diagnosed clinically by observing paradoxical respiration. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced inwards, and on expiration, it moves outwards.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Jackson-Pratt drain The given image is of a Jackson-Pratt drain. Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely drain the air or fluids that may accumulate. They promote wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains can be: - Open: They are based on the principle of gravity - Semi-open: Their action is based on capillary effect - Closed: They carry out their actions through suction

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument.

questions.text: The type of knot seen In the image is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reef knot The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen. A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Doyen’s mouth gag Doyen’s mouth gag is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on the molar teeth.

questions.text: Identify the given condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trophic ulcer The given picture showing an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point is most likely that of a trophic ulcer/neuropathic ulcer. A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 20 G The given cannula is 20 gauge IV cannula as its color code is pink.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with an indirect inguinal hernia. The surgeon uses the suture material given in the image below for the hernia repair. It is a polyamide polymer that undergoes degradation and loses tensile strength at the rate of 15-20% every year. Identify the suture material.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nylon The suture material is nylon. Nylon is a monofilament or braided multifilament type non absorbable suture material. It is a polyamide polymer with low tissue reaction and is used in skin closure, abdominal wall mass closure, hernia repair, plastic surgery, neurosurgery, microsurgery, ophthalmic surgery, etc. However, it also loses 15-20% of its tensile strength every year and degrades at the rate of 15-20% every year.

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.text: A young man with a history of blunt abdominal trauma was brought to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically unstable, and a FAST examination revealed free fluid. An immediate laparotomy was done. The maneuver shown in the image below was performed due to severe bleeding near the liver. However, the bleeding continued. What could be the probable source of the bleeding in this case? FAST-Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hepatic vein bleeding The image shows clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in the Pringle maneuver. Bleeding that is not controlled by this maneuver suggests that the source of the bleeding is the hepatic vein. The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists. After performing this maneuver, the liver laceration can be explored, and further bleeding can be controlled.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency room with bloody vomitus. Vital signs show a BP of 90/70 mm Hg, pulse 110 bpm, and SpO2-97%. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and a distended abdomen with spider nevi. The bleeding is immediately controlled using the instrument shown in the image. Identify the instrument?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sengstaken Blakemore tube The above image shows the Sengstaken Blakemore tube. The given clinical scenario- a chronic alcoholic with hematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding, in which temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades. Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. 1 suction tube and 2 inflation tubes. The 3 openings are the gastric balloon port, esophageal balloon port, and the gastric aspiration port Only gastric contents can be aspirated. Sengstaken-Blakemore tube should be decompressed every 12 hours to prevent necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below?.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Negative pressure wound therapy The given image shows negative pressure wound therapy using a vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) device to promote healing in chronic wounds. Principle: An intermittent negative pressure of -125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds. Indications: Chronic wounds (such as diabetic foot ulcers, stage III and IV pressure ulcers), traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

questions.text: The operating surgeon performed the following suture technique on the skin after appendicectomy surgery. This is called
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mattress suture This suture technique is called mattress suture. The type of mattress suture performed is horizontal mattress suture. It is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edge of the wound and moving horizontally and traverse once again both the edge of the wound and tie the knot.

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is being performed on a 35-year-old male patient, who presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His barium swallow showed a bird’s beak appearance near the gastroesophageal junction. What is the procedure performed on this patient known as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) POEM The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia, and the procedure shown above is called peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM). Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder caused due to the degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby causing a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. The patients present with a triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods, halitosis is present due to the accumulation of food. Patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. at a later stage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Partial penectomy. The most appropriate management for this patient with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis is partial penectomy. Carcinoma of the penis is commonly a squamous cell carcinoma. It arises from the skin of the glans penis or the prepuce. The lesion can be flat or warty in appearance. T1-confined to the skin T2-invades the corpus spongiosum or cavernosum. T3-invades the urethra T4-invades adjacent structures. The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and thus, the sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is helpful for evaluating the spread of penile cancer.

questions.text: A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown below. Which of the following will be the most common site for secondary metastasis in patients with this tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lungs The history and CECT mentioned in the above scenario are consistent with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. The most common site for secondary metastasis in RCC is the lungs, where they form secondaries commonly known as cannonball secondaries. The tumor is prone to extend into the renal vein and reach the lungs via circulation. RCC also metastasizes to the bone, lymph nodes, liver, adrenal glands, and brain. Para-aortic nodes are the first draining lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and an apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has this feature?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Type 3 The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia. Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia. Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

choices.text: It is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra
Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin
It does not cause urinary obstruction
Ventral chordee is a common association

questions.text: A newborn was found to have a following anomaly of the penile urethra while being examined by a pediatrician. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin The image showing a newborn having a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis is indicative of hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

choices.text: All patients with this condition should be evaluated for psychiatric conditions
Aperistalsis in the oesophageal body is the characteristic feature
Calcium channel blockers may be tried in mildly symptomatic patients
This condition is seen most often in female patients

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with difficulty swallowing food and liquids for the last two months. She also complains of a sensation of food getting stuck in her throat. She has had an intermittent burning sensation in her throat and chest during the last month. Further evaluation with barium swallow shows the findings below. Which of the following is false about her condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aperistalsis in the oesophageal body is the characteristic feature The above clinical picture and barium swallow showing a corkscrew appearance are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Aperistalsis of the oesophageal body is a characteristic finding in achalasia cardia, not DES. Diffuse Esophageal Spasm – It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Esophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. This condition is seen most often in female patients

choices.text: Decompression of cyst improves renal function

questions.text: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent left-sided flank pain. His brother passed away two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decompression of cyst improves renal function The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In such patients, decompression or deroofing of the cysts (Rovsing’s procedure) cannot restore normal renal function. ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males.

questions.text: You notice the following test is being performed by your senior on a 30-year-old patient having an Alvarado score of 7. The patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen on performing the test. What is the name given to this clinical sign?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Psoas sign The name given to this clinical sign is the Psoas sign. The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. A score of 7, as seen in this patient, suggests probable appendicitis. Various clinical signs have been described which are used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. Abdominal pain with hyperextension of the right hip is known as the Psoas sign. This is because of psoas muscle spasm, due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with this muscle. The patient often lies in a posture with the right hip flexed for pain relief.

questions.text: A patient with rectal prolapse underwent surgery. The postoperative image is given below. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thiersch wiring The postoperative image shows a purse-string suture which is suggestive of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse. In Thiersch’s wiring, a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape is placed around the anal canal. It is rarely done now due to post-operative problems like chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pelviureteric junction obstruction The delayed intravenous urogram (IVU) of the patient showing hydronephrosis with an absence of contrast in the ureter makes the likely diagnosis a pelviureteric junction obstruction. Pelviureteric Junction obstruction is the commonest type of urinary obstruction in childhood, but can also be seen in young adults. It is usually caused by intrinsic stenosis. It manifests as abdominal flank or back pain, and hematuria. In newborns, a renal mass is palpable.

questions.text: What is the appropriate age at which corrective surgery should be done for the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 6-18 months The image shows penoscrotal hypospadias. Operations for hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months

questions.text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute anal fissure The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures. Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

choices.text: Causes the most common type of gastritis
Associated with causation of gastric MALToma
Considered by WHO as class I carcinogen

questions.text: A biopsy was obtained from a patient with chronic peptic ulcer disease. The pathological slide is given below. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent of this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Causes hypogastrinemia The given slide shows the Gl mucosa, stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, infected with Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori cause hypergastrinemia. The ammonia released by H. pylori acts on the antral G-cells and releases gastrin. This is responsible for hypergastrinemia in these patients resulting in type B gastritis (the most common type of gastritis). Urea breath test and antibodies to H. pylori help us with diagnosis. The gold standard investigation for H. pylori is a tissue biopsy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD with epigastric pain, bloating, cough, and acid reflux. His symptoms subside slightly on taking antacids. He is being worked up for peptic ulcer disease. He has a gastric ulcer in the region of the stomach marked in the image below. What will be the type of ulcer in this case according to the Modified Johnson anatomical classification?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Type IV The above image shows type IV of the modified johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer. It is seen high along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is not related to increased gastric acid levels.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 24-h pH monitoring The given barium swallow shows a bird beak appearance and is suggestive of achalasia cardia. 24-h pH monitoring is not necessary for achalasia cardia. It is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. This is due to the loss of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.

choices.text: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier’s disease. Menetrier’s disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Putty kidney A patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria and the abdominal X-ray showing homogenous ground glass-like calcification is suggestive of a putty kidney. The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB). It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is always a secondary TB (reinfection or reactivation of old TB). Genitourinary TB usually presents as sterile pyuria. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. Microbiological diagnosis is confirmed by at least 3 consecutive early-morning urine samples showing acid-fast bacilli using Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain and subsequently cultured (gold standard).

questions.text: What instrument is required for the following procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cystourethroscope The instrument required for placing the Double J stent (DJ stent), as shown in the radiograph is a cystourethroscope Cystourethroscopy allows for the examination and access of the bladder and urethra, which is crucial for guiding the DJ stent from the bladder into the ureter. This procedure involves inserting a flexible or rigid endoscope through the urethra and into the bladder, where the stent can be manoeuvred into the ureter. While ureteroscopy is typically used to visualize and treat issues directly within the ureter, cystourethroscopy provides the necessary access and visualization to position the DJ stent correctly. This approach is effective for ensuring the stent is placed accurately, particularly in cases where access to the bladder is essential.

choices.text: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
Topical application of silver nitrate is done

questions.text: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring. Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week. Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of a-fetoprotein. An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a sac.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with abdominal pain and obstipation for 3 days. He gives a history of bull gore to the abdomen 3 days back. His X-ray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hollow viscus perforation The given clinical scenario involves a patient with a history of penetrating abdominal trauma and presenting symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation. The erect radiograph shows air under the diaphragm which strongly points to a diagnosis of hollow viscous perforation. Perforation of the alimentary tract is a life-threatening condition. This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: You observe a patient being operated upon in the given position in the operation theatre. What could be the likely surgery being performed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient’s head is elevated 15-30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level. The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.
